facts.text: Kadir Ali Bohra died on 5-4-1952 leaving behind five sons (Ghulam Abbas Defendant No. 1, Abdullah Defendant No. 2, Imdad Defendant No. 3, Kayyumali Plaintiff-Respondent, Nazarali Defendant No. 4), a daughter and his widow as his heirs.
Kadir Ali Bohra had incurred debts so heavily that all his property would have been swallowed up to liquidate these.

Three sons, Ghulam Abbas (Defendant No. 1), Abdullah (Defendant No. 2), and Imdad (Defendant No. 3), who had prospered, paid up the debts to save the property for themselves to the exclusion of Kayyumali (Plaintiff-Respondent) and Nazarali (Defendant No. 4).

On 10-10-1942, Kayyumali (Plaintiff-Respondent) and Nazarali (Defendant No. 4) executed deeds (Ex. D/2 and Ex. D/3) acknowledging receipt of cash and moveable properties as consideration for not claiming any rights in future in the properties mentioned, giving up their possible future rights.

The deeds stated: 'I have accordingly taken the things mentioned above as the equivalent of my share and I have out of free will written this. I have no claim in the properties hereafter and if I put up a claim in future to any of the properties I shall be proved false by this document. I shall have no objection to my father giving any of the properties to my other brothers.'
During the father's lifetime, when all chance or expectation of inheritance by Kayyumali or Nazarali could be destroyed by disposition of property, neither raised any objection.
Plaintiff (Kayyumali) was doing nothing and was in a way a burden to his father at the time of executing the release deeds.
Defendants Nos. 1, 2 and 3, with their labour and money, straightened the status of father Kadir Ali and cleared up the debts.
Partition suit filed by Plaintiff-Respondent Kayyumali against family members governed by Muslim law.

First Appellate Court (final court on facts) found that release deeds were executed when defendants 1,2,3 had cleared debts, plaintiff was burden; it was a family settlement to prevent future disputes, induced defendants to discharge debts; plaintiff estopped from claiming share.
High Court allowed second appeal, held consideration passed but Muslim law (like TPA s.6(a)) prohibits transfer of chance of inheritance (spes successionis), no estoppel against such rule.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court judgment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Plaintiff (Kayyumali) and Defendant No. 4 (Nazarali) are estopped by their declarations, conduct and silence from claiming their shares in the properties covered by the deeds.
Whether estoppel can arise against a rule of Muslim Personal Law prohibiting transfer or relinquishment of spes successionis (chance of inheritance), equated to s.6(a) TPA.
Whether the Madras High Court view (no estoppel) or Allahabad High Court view (estoppel possible via conduct) is correct.

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaintiff and Defendant No. 4 are estopped by their declarations in deeds, receipt of consideration, conduct and silence from claiming shares; deeds part of family settlement to prevent disputes, induced defendants 1,2,3 to pay debts.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 115 Evidence Act; family settlement principles

petitioner_arguments.text: Estoppel arises from course of conduct over years, even if no valid transfer under Muslim law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Allahabad HC in Latafat Hussain v. Hidayat Hussain; Evidence Act s.115

respondent_arguments.text: Rule of Muslim Personal Law prohibits transfer/relinquishment of spes successionis (chance of heir-apparent succeeding), same effect as s.6(a) TPA; no estoppel against statute or such rule.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Muslim Personal Law (Mulla ss.54); TPA s.6(a), s.2; Madras HC Abdul Kafoor v. Abdul Razack

respondent_arguments.text: Renunciation struck by s.23 Contract Act if defeats Muslim law provisions.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Contract Act s.23; Abdul Kafoor case

court_reasoning.text: Muslim law rule does not prohibit but declares no transferable right exists in spes successionis (inchoate, no right till death); nemo est heres viventis.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule clarifies what is transferable, not to protect recipients of consideration for non-existent right.

court_reasoning.text: Estoppel not against statute; deeds void as transfer but conduct (declarations, receipt of consideration, silence) creates equitable estoppel under s.115 Evidence Act as rule of evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Estoppel operates on conduct misleading owner, barring assertion of vested right later.

court_reasoning.text: Prefers Allahabad view (Latafat Hussain) over Madras (Abdul Kafoor); estoppel question under Contract/Evidence Act, not strictly Muslim law; family arrangement broad sense possible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Renunciation implied from ceasing to prosecute claim; in consonance with Muslim jurisprudence.

court_reasoning.text: Facts found by first appellate court (accepted by HC) show estoppel: deeds for consideration, no objection during life, induced debt payment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff cannot seek benefit against own undertakings.

holdings.text: Plaintiff and Defendant No. 4 estopped by conduct from claiming inheritance shares covered by deeds upon father's death.
Principle of estoppel (s.115 Evidence Act) applies despite Muslim law on spes successionis; no bar as rule not prohibitory but declaratory of non-existence of right.
Allahabad High Court view correct over Madras.

precedents_cited.relevance: Madras view no estoppel to defeat Muslim law; SC disagrees, not prohibited but no right.
Estoppel via conduct possible despite invalid relinquishment under Muslim law.
Full Bench: no transfer/renunciation of spes before vesting; preponderance of authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Valanhivil Kunchi v. Kengayil Pattikavil Kunbi Avulla
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Madras view without fresh reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kochunni Kachu Muhammed v. Kunj Pillai Muhammed

precedents_cited.relevance: Renunciation may be implied from ceasing to prosecute claim; no right during lifetime.
Opinion: renunciation of non-existent right void.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: s.6(a) chance of heir-apparent cannot be transferred; s.2 excludes Muslim law application but effect equated.

statutes_cited.name: Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Estoppel by conduct as rule of evidence barring assertion of right.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Madras view: renunciation struck down if defeats Muslim law; SC disagrees, no need as no transfer.

statutes_cited.name: Muslim Personal Law
statutes_cited.relevance: Chance of heir-apparent succeeding cannot be transferred/renounced before vesting (inchoate right).

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and decree of Madhya Pradesh High Court set aside; judgment and decree of first Appellate Court restored. Plaintiff and Defendant No. 4 barred by estoppel from claiming shares.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of first Appellate Court decree denying partition shares to Plaintiff and D4 in covered properties.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs.

key_quotes.text: "The only question before us now is whether the Plaintiff and Defendant No. 4 are estopped by their declarations and conduct and silence from claiming their shares in the properties covered by these deeds."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "An equitable estoppel operates, if its elements are established, as a rule of evidence preventing the assertion of rights which may otherwise exist."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains basis of estoppel applying despite Muslim law.

key_quotes.text: "Upon the facts and circumstances in the case found by the courts below we hold that the plaintiff and defendant No. 4 could not, when rights of inheritance vested in them at the time of their fathers death, claim these as such a claim would be barred by estoppel."
key_quotes.speaker: court
